title: Unannounced Visits
situation: A family member regularly drops by your home without calling first, expecting you to host them even when you’re busy.
question: How do you bring this up without making it a huge fight?

choices.label: Say nothing and keep accommodating them, even when it stresses you out.
choices.outcome: They assume it’s fine and keep doing it, while your resentment quietly builds.
choices.insight: Unspoken boundaries usually turn into quiet resentment instead of real change.

choices.label: Say, “I love seeing you, and I also need a heads-up. Can you text before you come over so I can tell you if it’s a good time?”
choices.outcome: They may be surprised but now understand your preference and what to do differently.
choices.insight: Naming what you want clearly—and offering a simple action—gives people something concrete to respect.

choices.label: Explode the next time they arrive and tell them they’re rude and selfish.
choices.outcome: They feel attacked and may focus on your tone instead of the real issue.
choices.insight: Waiting until you’re furious often makes the boundary conversation about the explosion, not the need.

title: Unwanted Life Advice
situation: A parent or relative criticizes your choices and offers unsolicited advice every time you share something about your life.
question: What do you say the next time it happens?

choices.label: Stop sharing anything with them so they have nothing to comment on.
choices.outcome: You protect yourself, but the relationship becomes shallow and distant.
choices.insight: Sometimes distance is needed, but if you never say why, there’s little chance of the pattern changing.

choices.label: Say, “When I share something, I usually just want you to listen unless I ask for advice. Could we try that?”
choices.outcome: They may slip up sometimes, but you’ve drawn a clear line between sharing and problem-solving.
choices.insight: You’re not asking them to change who they are—only how they respond in specific moments.

choices.label: Tell them they’re controlling and that you don’t need their opinion on anything ever again.
choices.outcome: They feel rejected and may become defensive or shut down.
choices.insight: Extreme statements can feel satisfying in the moment but leave little room for nuance or repair.
